Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the step-parent needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation2: Before starting a large-scale project tomorrow, the carpenter needs to read and interpret blueprints, drawings, and technical documents
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, bills spread out before me, the home loan repayment circled in red ink on the calendar. As a step-parent, I felt the weight of ensuring our family’s financial stability pressing down on my shoulders. The kids were counting on me, and I couldn’t let them down. But tomorrow, I was starting the biggest carpentry project I’d ever landed—a custom kitchen for a new client. Tonight, I needed to pore over blueprints and technical drawings, making sure every measurement was perfect, every joint planned. My mind kept drifting back to the loan, the numbers swirling in my head, while the stack of blueprints on the table seemed to grow taller by the minute. I knew I couldn’t afford any mistakes at work, not with so much riding on this job. But I also couldn’t ignore the family’s needs, the anxious look in my partner’s eyes when we talked about money. The demands of both roles pulled me in opposite directions, and I felt caught in the middle, unsure which responsibility to face first.
